PIONEER QUESTIONNAIRE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A LIST OF CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE PIONEER HISTORY OF SASKATCHEWAN

Peterman, Mrs. Elizabeth
Red Deer, Alta.

To Sask. - June, 1902.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES:
A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Peterman, Elizabeth
2. Your address: Red Deer, Alta., Canada
3. Date: March 15, 1902
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Kingsland, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? (Give name and occupation): John Peterman, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): June 30, 1898
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:

   In Wales, I was born there and lived there until I was about 18 years old. Then I moved to Liverpool, England, where I lived for about 10 years. After that, I came to Canada in 1898.

Q. What were your reasons for coming to Canada?

   We wanted to farm. My husband and I were both farmers, and we thought we could make a good living here.

Q. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

   My mother talked about it a lot, and she always told me how wonderful it was.

Q. How did you get to Canada?

   We came by ship from Liverpool to Quebec City, then by train to Winnipeg, and finally by horse-drawn cart to our homestead near Edmonton.

Q. What was your life like when you first arrived in Canada?

   It was very hard at first. We had to build our own house and clear the land for farming. It was a long and difficult journey, but we were determined to succeed.

Q. Did you face any challenges or difficulties during your time in Canada?

   Yes, we faced many challenges. The weather was harsh, and we had to work hard to survive. But we never gave up, and we eventually became successful farmers.

Q. How did you adapt to life in Canada?

   We adapted quickly. We learned to speak English and to work with the land. We also met many new friends who helped us settle in.

Q. What do you miss most about your time in Canada?

   I miss the freedom and the opportunity to start anew. It was a challenging time, but it was also very rewarding.

Q. What advice would you give to someone considering moving to Canada?

   I would tell them to be prepared for hard work and to have a positive attitude. It can be tough at first, but it will be worth it in the end.
Peterman, Mrs. Elizabeth
Red Deer Hill.
To Sask., June, 1923.

1. Your full name: Elizabeth J. Peterman
2. Your address: Red Deer Hill, Sask.
3. Date: March 15, 1923
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country) England, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? (Give name and occupation) Joseph Walter
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year) June 3rd, 1895
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

We moved to Canada in 1895 from England. We came by train and boat to Canada. We had been in Canada for about six months when we moved to Saskatchewan. My father was very hardworking and very kind.

My mother talked about her childhood and early life in England. She said she missed the countryside and the animals. She also mentioned how much she enjoyed the fresh air and the freedom to move around. She said she was very happy to be in Canada and felt at home there.

My father worked hard to provide for our family. He was very resourceful and always found ways to make ends meet. He was also very kind and generous to others.

We learned about the history of the area through our ancestors' stories. They told us about the early settlers and their struggles to survive in the harsh conditions. We also heard about the local wildlife and the plants they used for medicine.

We visited many historic sites and learned about the culture of the indigenous people. We also learned about the impact of European settlement on the land and its inhabitants.

We had a wonderful time exploring the area and learning about its rich history. We hope to visit again soon!

For Prince Albert, my husband had bought a lot of land and built a small house.

We then came from Prince Albert to Prince Albert, and then to Saskatoon.

We lived in a tent on a small farm near Saskatoon until we could afford a house.

After we moved to Prince Albert, we started working at the lumber yard.

We worked at the lumber yard and then moved to Prince Albert.

Traveling was quite hard, but we learned to adapt.
